comments.commentBody: We are working on it - -he, Harkin and Grassley all need to go.  I heard Harkin is moving on.

A good number of the decisions he makes as Finance Committee chair have little do do with this state of barely 1 million and 1 area code for the whole state.   The idea that he makes those choices based on what is best for the good folk of Montana is fantasy.

The article left out the story about how Intuit Corp. lobbies Sen. Baucus and others, arguing for even greater opaque complexity in the tax-code, intent on making it a veil of mysteries. Why? So Intuit can then sell even more of its tax-preparation software to a befuddled, exasperated American public.

The fundamental corruption rotting the heart of our political system laid bare for all too see.

I never voted for Max Baucus. I never sanctioned 27 of hi former taffer importuning him at every opportunity. I never voted for the obscene tax breaks he hand out regularly. Everything he does costs me more in taxes. K street lawyers and lobbyists raise the millions he says he needs to run for reelection. Other than his 27 former minions, how many of them are from Montana? The very small state of Montana elects him, but he has a disproportionate and baneful influence on the vast majority of Americans. The 1% love him, though.

Max Baucus told the U.S. how much he valued the American people when he drove a dagger into the heart of an expanded and improved Medicare for All, as well as, a strong public option.  He has always been another overpaid, over-pensioned, over health-benefited water-carrier for the 1% who needs to know what it's like to stand on an unemployment line or try to get health care in the Medicaid system.
Max Baucus is no friend of the American middle and working class.
Very well put.  Thank you.

The politicians should be ashamed of themselves.  Rather than stop this corporate welfare they want to take money from social security.  As usual, individual tax payers are paying more than their fair share for the wall street mess.
Montana does not represent a majority
We don't stand a chance in changing the tax laws.  It's too bad for the country and too bad for the majority of the population.  Romney was right.......
In other words, Mr Baucus is in the pockets of twenty eight lobbyists. No wonder Washington is as dysfunctional as it is and the government is at a standstill. Nothing is getting done.
The best government money can buy.

Oh Max, it's the American dream come true! Init?

Now you get to enrich yourself immensely and will finally get to use all the dirt that you've been collecting on your fellow senators and various and sundry public officials all these years.

You can't get much more brazenly corrupt than that. Good show! :-|
Absolutely. This corruption is destroying the country.

Sean Neary, a spokesman for Mr. Baucus, said the senator had regularly rejected requests from those lobbyists for provisions benefiting their clients, like an appeal from one former aide, Pat Bousliman, now working as a wind industry lobbyist, to extend an alternative energy loan guarantee program that expired in 2011".

Well of course the big donors have to be taken care of first.

No argument that white Union soldiers made the difference militarily and paid with their blood for a Union victory.  But African Americans didn't contribute only in military service to victory.  As a 2011 article in the NTHP magazine says, "Union generals and troops had realized from the beginning how African Americans in contraband camps could aid the war effort, especially by undertaking tasks white soldiers were loath to do. ... Women made significant contributions, growing cotton on abandoned plantations as part of a Union labor program, for example, or becoming cooks or hospital workers. And many runaways contributed valuable military intelligence, reporting on Confederate troop movements when they arrived at Union lines."   These were some of the support services to which I referred.  Also, such labor added to the Union cause was subtracted from the Confederate cause.  So historian Robert Engs has a point that the African American contribution was great and perhaps crucial.  It's also arguable that the African American exodus to freedom behind Union lines helped expand the focus of the war from saving the Union to ending slavery.  New perspectives don't necessarily equate with "political correctness."  The site of Fort Monroe, incidentally, was where the first African captives were introduced into the English colonies in 1619.  Hence this site encapsulates the English/ U.S. history of slavery in America.
I would recommend this a thousand times if I were permitted. Thank you for saying it-- this should be a NYTimes pick.

Should bemoan all the freedom I have lost? Being retired I have lost the freedom of relying and the charity of others instead of being burdened with the guaranteed retirement which Social Security provides. I have been denied the freedom of an early death without medical and hospital care and medicines provided by Medicare, which I could never have afforded out of my savings. This of course is an Orwellian tactic, called Newspeak, where war is peace and freedom is slavery, etc. It is intended to destroy the ability to communicate and to conceal the tactic of Doublethink which is employing opposite ideologues simultaneously.

It is amazing that the radical conservatives using the trademark “Republican,” are actually going about intentionally destroying freedom state by state. Their object is not liberty but a permanent one party state, one Republican state at a time, until our electoral system is destroyed. Women’s rights are being rolled back 60 years. Every year fewer and fewer citizens are permitted to vote. Districts are Gerrymandered until one man one vote is a joke. Everywhere freedom is under attack by Republicans and yet they can argue that they stand for freedom.

Obama sees the worst. They have destroyed democracy in Congress. The plan to overthrow the US government is progressing apace. If you want to keep a clear head and historical perspective, then imagine Republicans in uniforms, with GOP logo arm bands and carrying whips. Different, yes, but the same.

I would like to see one of these states passing gun restrictions actually require gun registration as a part of the Constitutional provision of a "well regulated militia."

I would love the "originalists" on the US supreme court to actually decide what "well regulated militia" means. They disregarded that clause in Heller.

Or, make them look like the hypocrites they are and decide it was the Founders who didn't understand what they meant.

Fine - but lets get the gun legislation passed first. This is not an "either/or" choice - there is no reason not to pursue multiple avenues to get this done. There is also no reason why a civilian needs an assault weapon and mega rounds in magazines - except to undertake mass killing.
I'd argue that the true mentally deranged are those who keep opposing bans on such weaponry in civilian hands.

The left's entire argument is that gun are dangerous. Let the president and Bloomberg not surround themselves (and others near them) with dangerous guns.   But no they and the rest of the left rather harass law abiding citizens. Criminals don't obey gun laws any more than they obey murder and other laws.

Why don't we demand that parents teach their kids that murder is illegal and wrong rather instead of blaming an inanimate object? The kid Newtown shooter had parents who were divorced. That in itself tells you a lot about their irresponsibility.

You think that matters to the gun control crowd? Any law that restricts gun ownership is, to them, a good law. They hate guns and they want them taken away from everyone. That is the only objective.

The problem with Adam Lanza apparently wasn't the fact that he was a murderous psychopath who wanted to kill schoolchildren, but the fact that guns exist in America.

I always find the deafening silence from the anti-gun crowd whenever an act of violence is committed with any means other than a gun interesting. Ever hear anything these folks after Oklahoma City?

The truth is that the gun grabbers really don't care about reducing crime, protecting people, or any of their other standard excuses for taking away firearms. They just hate guns and will use any event involving guns to further their agenda of taking away firearms.
And sadly in the next massacre.
26 people dead in five minutes. While we work on long-term solutions, we need to do as much as possible to protect people now.
And if you examine the nations around the world that have enacted gun legislation, you will see that gun violence is much much less than the violence we Americans are expected to tolerate.
